rows.name: Count by 1s

block1_text.eng:
Use number paths, number lines, and objects to help your students relate to the counting. As you do beginning counting together, point to the numbers on a number path or number line as they are said aloud. Counting objects, even your students, will help them see what the numbers they are saying mean.

Start with basic counting to a small number, such as 5. Slowly extend the range of the numbers and also the type of counting you do. Counting down is just as important as counting up.

**Steps:**
* **Count up by 1s from 0 and 1** – Keep counting things whenever you reference a count. If you want four books, count them out as you hand them over. Starting at 0 is important for making 0 a real number that has meaning to them.
* **Count down by 1s to 0 and 1** – Counting down is easy to do whenever you are counting down seconds or counting how many things are left as they are being removed. Counting down is also great to practice when your students are counting between 10 and 100 – they usually have to give a lot more thought to the transitions between decades, such as counting "72, 71, 70, 69, 68," and that thoughtfullness will lead to deeper understandings than just repeatedly counting upward.
* **Count On by 1s** – Perhaps you have 8 things to count. Count out a few of them and put them in a pile, say 3 of them. Then count the whole group by starting at 3 – "3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8."

rows.name: Skip Count by 2s, 5s, 10s

block1_text.eng:
The 2s, 5s, and 10s are the easiest and most natural skip count amounts to start with. As with counting by 1s, use objects and other references to make the counting more relateable. If you are counting objects, arranging them in an array sized by the skip count will help.

If you have a 100 Chart, circle the numbers as you count them. Because 2, 5, and 10 divide into 10, all the numbers will line up in columns.

It's just as important to practice skipping downward as upward.

* **Skip Count by 2s** – Skip counting by 2s is a natural thing to do. Tell your students it's a faster way to count when they have more than a few things. If they have trouble with this, you can have them say each skipped number very quietly. Encourage them to notice that all the numbers are even if they start at an even number, and they are all odd if they start at an odd number.
* **Skip Count by 10s** – The connection with place value makes this skip counting particularly important. It also makes it pretty easy. If you write the numbers down, or show them on a 100 Chart, your students will quickly notice that the digit in the ones column stays the same – discuss why that is.
* **Skip Count by 5s** – This follows naturally from skip counting by 10s. Only two digits will show up in the ones column, and only two columns in the 100 Chart will be visited.

rows.name: Skip Count – All

block1_text.eng:
The practice with 1s, 2s, 5s, and 10s, leads to this general skip counting. Skip counting by other numbers will not be as easy, but it is great practice for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Be sure to use any number as a starting point, not just multiples of the skip amount. 

**Ones Digits Patterns:** Keeping a record of the numbers on the board or on a 100 Chart will bring out some interesting patterns in the ones digits. Why do those happen? Skip counting by 1s, 3s, 7s, and 9s will hit every digit in the ones place. Skip counting by 2s, 4s, 6s, and 8s, will hit five of the digits. Skip counting by 5s will only hit two of the digits. See what sense your students can make of those patterns.

**Add Sub Fluency:** As your students get better at this, they can do skip counting at any time and in any place. This is a great way to improve their fluency with basic addition and subtraction facts.

rows.name: Beep Game

block1_text.eng:
This is a playful and competitive form of choral counting with a group of students in a circle. Specify a starting number, a skip amount, and a direction. Decide on a rule for saying "Beep." Someone starts by saying the first number, and then each person going around the circle either says the next number or they say "Beep" instead when the number satisfies the rule.

For example, you might say Beep for every multiple of 3 and any number ending in 3. Or you might say Beep for multiples of 4 and Boop for multiples of 5. All sorts of rules are possible. You can find out a little more about this game in the games section.
